STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 1, 2023
Kathleen Schultz
WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES KENTWOOD
1715 SUTHERLAND DR,
KENTWOOD, MI, 49508-3306
Re: License #: CB410201260
Dear Kathleen Schultz:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
June 1, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CB410201260
Licensee Group Organization: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Designee: DAVID M GEHM
Chief Administrator: Kathleen Schultz
Name of Agency: WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES
KENTWOOD
Agency Address: 1715 SUTHERLAND DR
KENTWOOD, MI 49508-3306
Agency Telephone #: 6162814601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American
Red Cross or other institution approved by the
department.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not have verification of current CPR/First
Aid training as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster
homes.
Four of six foster home files reviewed did not accurately document compliance with
a foster home licensing rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
2

(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the investigation shall not exceed
90 calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
One of three special investigations reviewed was not completed within 45 days and
there is no documentation the foster parents were notified in writing.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(a) The date the information was received.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not have a written report completed
within 15 days of the conclusion of the investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the
foster parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 days of completion as
required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
3

relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined in the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement
to a youth before placement in independent living.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the program statement prior to placement in
independent living as required.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the agency's policies and procedures as required.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
Two of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to the youth quarterly as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4

6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days as required.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14 days
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed and three of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
5

Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed and three of three independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
6

passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
7
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for treatment
and/or services prior to or at the first scheduled
appointment while the foster care case is open,
regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• • Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth aged
16
and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults aged
18 and older).
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
• Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
• Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Six of eight foster care files reviewed did not have all medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
5/28/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/30/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Check all applicable boxes in MISACWIS for FTM’s.
• Clearly label placement outlines.
• Semi-annual forms need to be uploaded within 7 days like the DHS 1105.
7

• Be sure to link all social work contacts to service plans.
• Upload renewal letter sent to foster parents.
• Verbal findings to foster parents during special investigations shouldn’t be
provided while investigation is still ongoing.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. A special evaluation was initiated on 6/7/2022 regarding allegations a
licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline. The foster
parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A CAP was
approved and has been successfully completed.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. SIR
2022C0212021 was initiated on 7/28/2022 regarding allegations the agency did
not follow licensing rules and agency policy regarding replacement of a foster
youth. Additional findings noted the agency did hold a placement disruption FTM
and the DHS 69 was not completed as required. A CAP was approved on
10/6/2022 and continues to be implemented.
SIR 2023C0000073 was initiated on 12/2/2022 regarding allegations the agency
did not have a visitation plan that assured the safety and wellbeing of a foster
youth, and a staff member did not perform duties assigned. A CAP was approved
on 1/11/2023 and continues to be implemented.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 6/7/2022 with a corrective action plan approved
on 6/28/2022. During the review the agency had nine violations. Six violations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted by staff turnover
and workforce challenges.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting some of the
requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the
previous year CAP was effective and the agency has taken many steps they feel
have been helpful in achieving compliance, especially regarding repeat violations.
Some of the action steps from the previous year CAP were delayed or needed to
8

be reevaluated. The CA reported the agency struggled with staff turnover and
workforce challenges that impacted compliance in various ways. However, the CA
stated the agency has focused on ongoing training and support with new staff. The
CA indicated the agency has implemented new processes based on the previous
year CAP and they feel it has assisted in meeting compliance. The CA expressed
confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported there are
good systems in place to track and manage workloads. Staff reported supervisors
and coworkers are supportive and willing to help out as needed. Staff reported no
areas of concern.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
________6/1/2023____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 1, 2023
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
